data.title: TV shows and movies based on books you can watch at home for Book Lovers Day
data.meta_description: Friday, August 9 is Book Lovers Day. To mark the occasion, here are some TV shows and movies based on books you can watch in the comfort of your own home.
data.text:
With Book Lovers Day falling on Friday, August 9, ABC News has compiled a list of TV shows and movies you can watch at home that are based on books.

The first cab of the rank is two-time Emmy nominee The Tattooist of Auschwitz.

Based on the eponymously titled novel by Heather Morris, it's the real-life story of Lale Sokolov, a Jewish prisoner who was tasked with tattooing ID numbers on prisoners' arms in the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp during World War II.

It's available on Stan.

A Good Girl's Guide To Murder

Pip Fitz-Amobi is uncertain whether schoolgirl Andie Bell was murdered by her lover, Sal Singh, five years ago. If it turns out that Sal is not the killer, how far will people go to keep Pip from uncovering the truth?

Available on Stan.

Bridgerton

This writer is a big fan of Bridgerton, the Shondaland-produced historical romance series based on the books by Julia Quinn.

Penelope Featherington enters season 3 finally ready to give up her longtime crush on Colin Bridgerton. But that doesn't mean she's done with love. Ooh. Juicy.

Available on Netflix.

All the Light We Cannot See

Based on the novel of the same name by Anthony Doerr, All the Light We Cannot See is a four-part limited series that follows the stories of blind French girl Marie-Laure and German soldier Werner whose paths cross in occupied France during World War II.

See it on Netflix.

Lessons in Chemistry

This brilliant series is based on a book by Bonnie Garmus.

In the 1950s, Elizabeth Zott's dream of being a scientist is challenged by a society that says women belong in the domestic sphere; she accepts a job on a TV cooking show and sets out to teach a nation of housewives way more than recipes.

Available on Apple TV+.

Disclaimer

Available to stream from October 11 and starring Australians Cate Blanchett, Leila George and Kodi Smit-McPhee, Disclaimer is based on a book by Renée Knight.

When an intriguing novel appears on Catherine's bedside table, she curls up and begins to read. But as she turns the pages she is horrified to realise she is a key character, a main player. This story will reveal her darkest secret. A secret she thought no-one else knew.

See it on Apple TV+.

Killers of the Flower Moon

Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI is originally a 2017 non-fiction book by American journalist David Grann about the Osage murders.

The Martin Scorsese film stars Lily Gladstone, Leonardo DiCaprio and Robert De Niro.

Available on Apple TV+.

Interview with the Vampire

Based on Anne Rice's iconic novel, Interview with the Vampire is about Louis de Pointe's epic story of love, blood and the perils of immortality, as told to the journalist Daniel Molloy.

Available on ABC iview.

Plum

Based on Brendan Cowell's novel of the same name, Plum follows Peter "The Plum" Lum (Brendan Cowell), a 49-year-old national football treasure who lives with his son Gavin (Vincent Miller) and girlfriend Charmaine (María Dupláa) in Cronulla. It looks like Plum is living the dream until he discovers he has a brain disorder as a result of the hundreds of head knocks and concussions he suffered on the field. Plum also stars Asher Keddie.

Coming soon to ABC TV and ABC iview.

Fake

Inspired by Stephanie Wood's memoir of the same name, magazine features writer Birdie Bell (Asher Keddie) meets successful grazier Joe Burt (David Wenham) on a dating app and believes she's found her perfect match, but as the relationship intensifies she begins to feel her boyfriend isn't all he has led her to believe.

Available on Paramount+.

The Godfather

It's a classic!

Don Vito Corleone, head of a mafia family, decides to hand over his empire to his youngest son, Michael. However, his decision unintentionally puts the lives of his loved ones in grave danger.

Based on the 1969 novel by Mario Puzo.

See it on Paramount+.

Last King of the Cross

Last King of the Cross follows John Ibrahim's journey from a poverty-stricken immigrant to becoming Australia's most notorious nightclub mogul. Based on the memoir of the same name.

Available on Paramount+.

Fifty Shades of Grey

The novel of the same name sold a ridiculous number of copies. Having read it, I do not understand why.

The film stars Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan.

Ana, a college student, interviews an enigmatic billionaire entrepreneur, Christian, for her campus periodical. A steamy sadomasochistic affair starts between the two, whose roots lie in his past.

See it on Binge.

The Last Anniversary

Based on bestselling Australian author Liane Moriarty's novel of the same name, The Last Anniversary is set on Scribbly Gum Island, a place of many secrets. The one that made it famous – the disappearance of a young couple decades ago – might have made the island a destination for true crime tourists but when it comes to secrets, the three generations of women that call Scribbly Gum home hold far more.

Coming soon to Binge.

Game of Thrones

Based on the books by George R R Martin, if you missed the cultural juggernaut that is Game of Thrones, you can binge each and every episode.

See it on Binge.
